image.altText: Anne Pedler with two young boys.

items.synopsis: A coroner blasts a Tasmanian hospital over the death of a woman, noting her illness was "underestimated in the extreme" and that she spent eight hours in an ambulance outside the facility as "no bed [was] available for her" due to a "lack of nursing staff on duty".

title.children: 'There was no-one there for her': Daughter mourns mum as coroner lashes hospital where 71yo died while ramped

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: The RBA has left interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. It leaves the cash rate at its highest level since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: RBA warns another rate hike may be on the cards despite holding off in August

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian investors liked the news that the Reserve Bank was keeping interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent, an 11 year high. The ASX 200 index put on 0.5 per cent with technology, industrial and consumer firms doing the best because they benefit from lower interest rates. Energy stocks, miners and banks were among the gainers. The only sector that fell today were education stocks. And the Australian dollar tumbled by 1 per cent to 66.56 US cents because the cost of borrowing did not go up. Investors think that the RBA could be done with its rate hiking cycle. TPG Telecom (+11.6 per cent) was the best performer, while Credit Corp (-12.6 per cent) did the worst.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX ends higher as RBA pauses rate hikes

children.content: Australian investors liked the news that the Reserve Bank was keeping interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent, an 11 year high.
The ASX 200 index put on 0.5 per cent with technology, industrial and consumer firms doing the best because they benefit from lower interest rates.
Energy stocks, miners and banks were among the gainers.
The only sector that fell today were education stocks.
And the Australian dollar tumbled by 1 per cent to 66.56 US cents because the cost of borrowing did not go up.
Investors think that the RBA could be done with its rate hiking cycle.
TPG Telecom (+11.6 per cent) was the best performer, while Credit Corp (-12.6 per cent) did the worst.

props.alt: Best and worst performers on ASX 200

children.content: ASX movers
(Refinitiv)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tim's question is a really important reminder that if you're doing it tough at the moment in this high interest rate environment (or know someone who is) that there are plenty of resources available. If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access. National Debt Helpline : 1800 007 007 Mob Strong Debt Help : 1800 808 488 ASIC's Moneysmart website Australian Financial Complaints Authority Find a financial counsellor Lifeline : 13 11 14 Beyond Blue : 1300 224 636 (This is general information only, and if you require financial advice, please seek out a professional.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If you're struggling with higher interest rates, help is available

children.content: Tim's question is a really important reminder that if you're doing it tough at the moment in this high interest rate environment (or know someone who is) that there are plenty of resources available.
If you're experiencing financial distress, there are a number of support services available for you to access.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What's the best approach for those homeowners whose fixed rate mortgages will expire shortly. Fix again for 1 or 2 years or move to a flexible rate? - Tim. Hey Tim, We can't provide you advice on what the best course of action is to take with your mortgage — we aren't licensed to do so (it's also why we have that little disclaimer at the top of the blog). That said, there are thousands of home owners who are coming off their fixed rate and are bracing for the impact of these higher rates. A couple of months ago our colleague Stephanie Chalmers pulled together this handy guide if you're already struggling with mortgage repayments. But if you're trying to get ahead of the curve, we've also got you covered. Emily Stewart asked the experts this very question last year, and pulled together this quick guide to help you prepare — and who to ask for advice. I've linked it below for you to have a read of (or you can bookmark it for another day).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: My fixed rate mortgage is expiring soon, what is the best approach?

featuredLink.title: 'Start preparing for the mortgage cliff while you can', experts warn fixed rate borrowers

children.content: What's the best approach for those homeowners whose fixed rate mortgages will expire shortly. Fix again for 1 or 2 years or move to a flexible rate?
- Tim

image.altText: Zane Mellor in a pool reaches for the camera.

image.altText: A desert kurrajong tree sits against a purple night sky.

image.altText: Scott Morrison in Question Time.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Scott Morrison a 'bottomless well of self-pity', Bill Shorten says of Robodet scheme

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In today's question time in federal parliamentm NDIS Minister Bill Shorten spoke about the robodebt scheme and took aim at Scott Morrison. Shorten criticised Scott Morrison's comments he made yesterday in response to the Royal Commission's findings on his role in robo debt. "The member for Cook then said the royal commission was a quasi-legal process, a new Morrisonian doctrine about the law," he told the parliament. "The royal commission was not quasi-legal, it is real and constituted by the law," Shorten said. "46 days of public hearings, over 100 witnesses under oath." Shorten then said he could see Morrison, the Member for Cook lip syncing something in response. "The Member for Cook is a bottomless well of self-pity and not a drop of mercy for all of the real victims of robodebt."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Scott Morrison has 'not a drop of mercy for real victims of robodebt' says Bill Shorten

children.content: In today's question time in federal parliamentm NDIS Minister Bill Shorten spoke about the robodebt scheme and took aim at Scott Morrison.
Shorten criticised Scott Morrison's
comments he made yesterday
in response to the Royal Commission's findings on his role in robo debt.
"The member for Cook then said the royal commission was a quasi-legal process, a new Morrisonian doctrine about the law," he told the parliament.
"The royal commission was not quasi-legal, it is real and constituted by the law," Shorten said.
"46 days of public hearings, over 100 witnesses under oath."
Shorten then said he could see Morrison, the Member for Cook lip syncing something in response.
"The Member for Cook is a bottomless well of self-pity and not a drop of mercy for all of the real victims of robodebt."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank has left interest rates on hold for the second month in a row for the first time since it started raising them in May last year. The RBA's cash rate target will remain at 4.1 per cent following today's board meeting. You can read more about what that means on our business blog.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reserve Bank leaves cash rate on hold at 4.1 per cent

featuredLink.title: Live: RBA leaves interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent

children.content: The Reserve Bank has left interest rates on hold for the second month in a row for the first time since it started raising them in May last year.
The RBA's cash rate target will remain at 4.1 per cent following today's board meeting.
You can read more about what that means on our business blog.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reuters news agency reports that Russian anti-aircraft units have downed drones in Moscow today, but officials say one drone, allegedly sent out of control by anti-aircraft activity, hit the same high-rise tower that was impacted earlier this week. Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says the tower at Moskva Citi has been damaged, with "glazing destroyed over 150 square metres". No injuries have been reported. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Another drone has hit a Moscow high-rise tower

featuredLink.title: Moscow mayor accuses Ukraine of drone strike on city buildings

props.alt: A close up of exterior glass windows of a skyscrapper wich have been badly damaged on a small number of floors

The Reuters news agency reports that Russian anti-aircraft units have downed drones in Moscow today, but officials say one drone, allegedly sent out of control by anti-aircraft activity,
hit the same high-rise tower that was impacted earlier this week
Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin says the tower at Moskva Citi has been damaged, with "glazing destroyed over 150 square metres".
No injuries have been reported.
